Mike, you argue quite a lot in favour of only using link-reltypes. For 
instance in http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/18337:

> There are also server and client perspectives of the
> interaction which *do* include these semantics - *established for a
> URI by the server and shared with the client via some hypertext
> control*. This has to happen otherwise neither would have a frame of
> reference for how to make or receive the request. i.e. hypertext is
> the mechanism by which shared understanding is exposed and controlled
> in REST applications.

And in http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/18322:

> In this example the shared understanding is really coming from the link 
> relations.
> Link relations can exist independently from the media type, which is how
> shared understanding is established when using generic (hyper)media types.

So, in short, "hypertext is the mechanism by which shared understanding is 
exposed and controlled in REST applications.".

If you follow this logic then you could even argue that media-types in 
headers are completely irrelevant. All you need to do is to decorate the 
link-reltypes with the possible media-type. Instead of one link with reltype 
"salesorder" you could have "salesorder-xml", "salesorder-pdf", 
"salesorder-IBM", and so on - and throw away content negotiation at the same 
time.

But it builds on a false assumption of always following a link-reltype. Here 
is a couple of examples where it won't work:

- A friend sends you a link to an image. You click on it and have absolutely 
no link-reltype to indicate what kind of stuff you will get. "Luckily" the 
server returns content-type: image/jpeg such that your browser knows how to 
handle it.

- A spidering service is presented with a bunch of URLs it should index. It 
has no apriori knowledge of what to get from those URLs. Again the server 
returns a usefull content-type and magic happens (and application/xml is not 
usefull from this prspective).

- The <img src="..."/> has no link-reltype stating "this is a JPEG" or "this 
is a GIF". It relies on the returned content-type (and content negotiation 
with the accept header).

- A paper bussiness card contains a URL to the digital representation of it. 
What if the server returns "application/xml"? How would you know how to 
decode it? Luckily it returns "application/vcard+xml" (or "text/vcard" or 
...).

- A price comparing services trawls through whatever URLs it can pick up 
from the internet, looking for media-types "application/vnd.sap.pricing+xml" 
(fictive) and "application/open-pricing+xml" (also fictive). When ever it 
finds those it will read prices and accumulate a database of them.

My last example is what I think is most important. Here is what would happen 
if we only use application/xml and link-reltypes:

a) The client retrieves a hypertext document from server A.

b) The hypertext document contains a link with reltype 
"this-is-an-imageprocessor-of-type-X" that links to server B which is not 
under the control of server A.

c) The client follows the link sending an accept header with "Accept: 
application/xml".

d) The server returns "Content-type: application/xml" and, well, some XML.

e) Unfortunately server B has been upgraded without informing server A (how 
should it, it is a truely distributed system with independent components). 
So it instead of returning XML for "imageprocessor-of-type-X" (as the 
link-reltype told the client) it now returns XML for 
"imageprocessor-of-type-Y".

f) The client breaks.

If instead the client had sent "Accept: application/imageprocesser-x+xml" 
then the server would have known that it should return the old format - or a 
redirect to a server capable of working with the expected format.

By utilizing not only link-reltypes but also media-types we make it possible 
to work in a truely distributed network system where the servers as well as 
clients are free to change over time without any kind of coordination.

The link-reltype tells the client what link to follow - the media-type in 
the accept header tells the server what the client expects from it - 
something that the server cannot know otherwise.

The fact is that link-reltypes are not enough. Thinking so does not take the 
nature of truely distributed applications into account. It builds on the 
assumption that the resource that contains the link is coupled/synchronized 
with the resource that it points to. I think Jan has been trying to say this 
a couple of times - here is my interpretation of it.

We need something more than link-reltypes and media-types is the answer to 
that.
